text:
Jerk Chicken was cruising down the sunlit streets of Kingston, the aroma of spices wafting through the open windows of his vibrant yellow car. He had just finished a successful catering gig, the satisfaction of serving up his famous dish still buzzing in his veins. Suddenly, flashing lights danced in his rearview mirror. 

“Just a routine stop,” he muttered, pulling over to the side. The officer approached, a stern look on his face. “Good afternoon, sir. License and registration, please.”

As Jerk Chicken fumbled through his glove compartment, his heart raced. He was a law-abiding citizen, but the sight of the handgun resting on the passenger seat made his stomach drop. It was a relic from his days in the city’s rougher neighborhoods, a reminder of a life he had left behind. 

“Is that your firearm?” the officer asked, eyes narrowing. 

Jerk Chicken swallowed hard, his mind racing. “Yes, officer. I... I forgot it was there. I don’t use it anymore. I’m just trying to make a living, you know?”

The officer studied him, the tension thick in the air. “You know it’s illegal to have a weapon without a permit, right?”

“I do, officer. I’m sorry. I’ll get rid of it, I promise.” 

After a long pause, the officer sighed, his expression softening. “Alright, I’ll let you off with a warning this time. Just remember, it’s not worth the risk.” 

Relief washed over Jerk Chicken as he nodded, grateful for a second chance.
